item.title: Does international migration make people happy?
item.description:
I gave a lightning talk at the BiB’s Turning Gold conference about shifts in subjective well-being in the course of international migration—a study with Nico Stawarz, Andreas Ette, and Heiko Rüger (all BiB).

Using unique longitudinal data that includes actual migration events (GERPS), we find robust evidence that the subjective well-being of internationally mobile individuals increases notably with their move abroad (picture).

item.title: Cultural distance and immigrant adjustment
item.description:
Abstract

The cultural distance (CD) between the country of origin and destination country of migrants has long been considered important for adjustment in international migration. Past research has mainly followed a cost perspective, pointing to rising costs in adjustment with increasing CD, postulating a negative linear relationship. Following this logic, previous studies overlooked potential benefits of CD for adjustment. We address this gap by taking a more differentiated perspective on CD and adjustment. Using unique probability-based survey data on German migrants in 38 destination countries with a maximum length of stay of 36 months, we examined different CD-levels and their consequences for adjustment. We ran multilevel regressions for sociocultural and psychological adjustment. Importantly, our findings indicate that the CD effect on adjustment is not linear but clearly resembles an inverted-U shape for both adjustment dimensions. This result challenges the cost perspective and suggests an “optimal” range of intermediate CD as most beneficial for recent migrants’ adjustment. We conclude that the prevailing view on the consequences of CD for migrant adjustment holds true for very large CDs, but it underestimates the challenges for culturally close migrants and overlooks that a certain level of cultural dissimilarity can facilitate migrants’ adjustment.

item.title: International migration and subjective well-being
item.description:
Abstract

In many economically highly-developed countries, a relevant proportion of the population migrates across national boundaries every year. For these individuals, migrating abroad not only comes with advantages (e.g. monetary returns) but also with potential pitfalls, because migration is accompanied by profound changes in everyday life. However, only few and mainly cross-sectional studies about individuals’ migration expierences exist, analysing the effects of migration on their quality of life. This study addresses these lacunae and investigates shifts in subjective well-being (SWB) of internationally mobile German citizens. We apply fixed effects (FE) panel regression models to data of the German Emigration and Remigration Panel Study (GERPS). To observe SWB in the course of migration, we draw on a sample of repeat migrants—Germans who returned to Germany shortly before the panel and migrated again across international borders during the panel. As counterfactuals, we focus on Germans who returned to Germany shortly before the panel but stayed there. Overall life satisfaction is used as an SWB-indicator, which corresponds to a global assessment of one’s life situation. In sum, our analyses reveal a happiness dip before migration as well as an increased and relatively stable SWB at the pre-migration baseline level in the first two years after migration.
